Unfortunately, I cannot see the graph image you are referring to. However, I can provide you with a general approach to finding the chromatic index of a graph.

The chromatic index of a graph, denoted by χ'(G), is the smallest number of colors needed to color the edges of the graph such that no two adjacent edges share the same color. To find the chromatic index, you can follow these steps:

1. Determine the maximum degree of the graph, denoted by Δ(G), which is the highest number of edges connected to any single vertex.

2. Check if the graph is regular, meaning that every vertex has the same degree. If the graph is regular and has an odd degree, then the chromatic index is equal to the maximum degree, χ'(G) = Δ(G).

3. If the graph is not regular or has an even degree, you can use the Vizing's theorem, which states that the chromatic index of a graph is either equal to the maximum degree or one more than the maximum degree, i.e., χ'(G) = Δ(G) or χ'(G) = Δ(G) + 1.

4. To determine which of the two values from Vizing's theorem is the correct chromatic index, you can try to color the edges using Δ(G) colors. If you can successfully color all the edges without any adjacent edges sharing the same color, then χ'(G) = Δ(G). Otherwise, χ'(G) = Δ(G) + 1.
